p: Contemporary human influenza virus strains have circulated in human populations for many decades, undergoing selection for resistance to human immunity as well as enhanced transmission during that period. Glycosylation of influenza virus HA, especially for A(H3N2) viruses, has been shown to have a major impact on antigenicity and is an important factor in antigenic drift [ 74]. However, increasing glycosylation of HA molecule has also been correlated with decreased virulence, a change in tropism from the lower to the upper RT, and diminished enhancement of secondary bacterial lung infections [ 75]. This suggests that increasing levels of glycosylation may both enhance influenza immune evasion in the presence of population adaptive immunity, and also reduce viral virulence or replication ability in non-immune individuals.
